Dear Nicole Lawson:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
Section (1) Upon receipt of any information that relates to possible
Description noncompliance with any foster home rule, the agency must do the
following:
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as
indicated, based on the information received, but not later than 7
calendar days after receipt of the information.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The family accepted placement on 10/2/23 and abruptly dropped
of the child’s belonging to the agency without providing the agency
14-day notice and the agency did not initiate a special
investigation.
Investigation Licensing worker (LW) was interviewed on November 8, 2023,
via video conference. LW stated she was the assigned licensing
worker for Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 at the time Youth
A was placed in their home. LW stated there was no conversation
regarding Foster Parent 1(FP1) and Foster Parent 2(FP2) ending
placement with Youth A without providing 14 days’ notice.
Licensing supervisor (LS) was interviewed on November 8,
2023, via telephone. LS stated she was not directly assigned at
the time Youth A’s placement with FP1 and FP2 ended however
the stance the agency takes is when foster parents report they do
not feel safe it is not questioned. LS stated that based on
language in the TA manual it outlines foster parents may request
youth be moved more quickly if their presence in the home
jeopardizes the safety of the youth or members of the household.
She stated FP1 and FP2 were adamant they did not feel safe in
the home. Upon Youth A’s removal from the home, he was placed
in inpatient hospital.
Foster Parent 1 (FP1) and Foster Parent 2 (FP2) were
interviewed together on November 15, 2023, via telephone.
FP2 stated the service needs the family was willing to consider
listed in the licensing home study (3130) was accurate. However,
their concern was they were not made aware of all of Youth A’s
diagnosis prior to him being placed in their home. She further
explained they were not able to provide the required 14-day notice
to the agency due to an emergency situation where they were not
receiving appropriate responses from professionals involved with
Youth A and, as a result, felt unsafe to continue the placement.
2

Licensing supervisor 2 (LS2) was interviewed on November
21, 2023, via telephone. She stated she has been the assigned
licensing supervisor since just after FP1 and FP2 became
licensed in May 2023. LS2 stated Youth A’s assigned caseworker
contacted the agency via the emergency after hours phone and
reported Youth A had been taken to the hospital by FP1 and FP2
and he would not be placed back in their care upon discharge due
to Youth A’s behaviors in the home and concern for their safety.
She stated the agency’s stance when a foster parent report they
do not feel safe they will not continue with the placement.
Documents reviewed:
• Youth A’s placement record while placed with FP1 and FP2
included a documented timeline while he was in their care
from October 2, 2023-October 10, 2023. The timeline
states Youth A’s behavior escalated on October 9, 2023,
and into October 10, 2023. He started to make verbal
threats to run away and injure himself, he began yelling at
FP1 and FP2, and was followed by threats to physically
injure FP1.
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case record. Social work contact
dated October 10, 2023, at 10:46am includes a text
message sent from FP1 to Youth A’s assigned case worker
that reads: “WE DO NOT FEEL SAFE WITH HIM IN OUR
HOME!!! If I need to get an attorney, I will. He threatened
me as we left the house. Said if we were going somewhere
he didn’t like he was going to start swinging at me. Plus
with the social worker’s recommendations, we do not feel
safe!!!”
• Youth A’s placement record documents he was in inpatient
hospital placement from October 10, 2023-October 25,
2023.
• Social work contact dated October 19, 2023, at 10:45 am.
Youth A continues to meet criteria for inpatient
hospitalization.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there is documentation
within Youth A’s MISACWIS case record that FP1 and FP2
reported to the assigned caseworker they no longer felt safe while
he was placed in their home. In addition, interviews with LS and
LS2 verify the agency did not initiate a special evaluation based
on the foster parents reporting they did not feel safe to continue
placement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12325 License recommendation
Section (1) An agency shall recommend to the department the appropriate
Description licensing action consistent with facts contained in the foster
home evaluation and any special evaluations.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Orchards Children’s Services placed an intensive needs child into
a new foster home open less than six months. Adequate training
nor foster care experience was established for the foster parents
prior to placement of this child.
Investigation Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on November 7,
2023, via telephone. She stated the agency did not have case
management responsibility for Youth A’s case, but their agency
was contacted for placement purposes. The intake worker
received an email from the Intensive Placement Unit looking for
placement for Youth A and she contacted FP1 and FP2.
Licensing supervisor (LS) was interviewed on November 8,
2023, via telephone. She stated the initial home study was
started by another worker in her office, but she conducted the
home visit with FP1 and FP2 and completed the report. She
acknowledged the family did not have a lot of specific training
regarding some of the service types they were approved for but
stated the family was adamant that they had connections in their
community that are part of the mental health field. In addition,
FP1’s adult daughter had a lot of past mental health needs. As a
result, the family conveyed they felt prepared to adequately
handle the specific service needs identified in the initial home
study. LS stated she uses a variety of information when assessing
the service needs that foster parents are approved for. She stated
she takes into account the information provided during GROW
training, personal experience, or outside training experiences. She
stated she also assesses based on conversation with the family to
gage their ability to care for youth with certain service needs.
LS stated FP1 and FP2 had also expressed interest in training
opportunities that were specific to the service types they were
approved for. LS stated they were offered additional training
opportunities through the agency. Upon licensure, the agency
adds contact information for foster parents, and they receive
training opportunities via email and USPS mail and support
groups are sent to them.
Intake worker (IW) was interviewed on November 8, 2023, via
telephone. IW stated as part of her role she fields inquiries
regarding youth that are in need of placement. She had received
previous emails regarding Youth A stating he was ready for a
4

community placement. She reviewed the agency vacancy list
previously but did not have a placement that matched his needs.
She stated the license for FP1 and FP2 had recently opened so
she contacted them regarding Youth A. She stated she provided
them some information. She was in contact with Youth A’s foster
care worker from another agency and a family team meeting was
set up that included Youth A, his foster care worker, IW, FP1 and
FP2. During the meeting Youth A and his foster care worker
provided some background information and answered any
questions that came up. She stated after that there was email
communication between FP 2 and Youth A’s foster care worker.
She was included in the emails, but she was not part of further
conversation regarding Youth A being placed with FP1 and FP2.
She stated she had some correspondence with FP2 who had
asked for additional training she could complete. At that point, IW
connected FP2 with training staff within the agency. Intensive
Placement Unit contacted IW regarding Youth A. She stated they
sent her his write up, his MARE video and indicated he had made
a lot of progress and ready for a community setting. In general,
upon receiving placement inquiry emails, IW will reach out to
foster parents that have an opening and explain the information
that was provided to her. Generally, the placement write up does
not have a lot of information. She will reach out to the assigned
foster care worker if more information is needed, or prospective
foster parents have any questions. Once the foster parents and
foster care worker connect, she allows the assigned worker to
provide additional information or answer specific questions about
a youth.
Foster Parent 1 (FP1) and Foster Parent 2 (FP2) were
interviewed together on November 15, 2023, via telephone.
FP2 stated the service needs the family was willing to consider
listed in the 3130 was accurate. However, their concern was they
were not made aware of all of Youth A’s diagnosis prior to him
being placed in their home. FP1 stated they participated in GROW
training in summer 2022. He stated there is a lot of information
that is provided, however, there is not an adequate assessment of
the information retained and being able to put the information to
practice when a youth is placed in their home. FP1 stated they
attended one additional training after initial licensure the agency
offered related to trauma and brain functioning. FP2 stated they
were initially contacted by IW regarding Youth A and a few other
youth inquiring about possible placement. She stated IW was
familiar with the service needs the family was willing to consider
and not willing to consider. Regarding Youth A, IW described his
profile and stated she did not see any concerns based on the
5

information she had, and the service needs they were willing to
accept. IW connected FP1 and FP2 with Youth A’s assigned
foster care worker. FP1 stated he reported to the agency his now
adult daughter was diagnosed with ADHD and based on that he
felt comfortable caring for a child with that diagnosis. He did not
state personal experience with any of the other service needs
listed in the recommendation section of the initial home study
(3130).
Documents reviewed:
• 3130 completed on May 19, 2023.
FP training: Orientation and training hours credited; include
topics covered. FP2 completed the following training and
verification/certificates can be found in the file: 3 hours of
orientation on 4/13/22. - 25 hours of GROW Training on
7/11/22, 7/12/22, 7/13/22, 7/18/22, 7/19/22, and 7/21/22.
This included the following sessions: Introduction, Child
Development, Systems, Policies and Advocacy, Attachment
and Relationships, Diversity and Inclusion, Toxic Stress,
Trauma, and Trauma Informed Parenting, Foster, Adoptive
and Kinship Parent Wellbeing, Mental Health and Special
Needs, Conclusion, Adoption Panel, Safe Sleep and
Prudent Parenting. 2 hours of CPR training on 10/9/22
through eCPRcertification.com that expires on 10/9/24.
1 hour of first aid training on 8/8/22 through
eCPRcertification.com that expires on 8/8/24.
The family believes that they could benefit from training on
trauma, children's needs, resources, and behaviors.
Worker’s assessment of additional training needs and the
agency’s plan to provide the identified training. It is
recommended that the family get involved with monthly
support groups. They will also be mailed and emailed about
monthly training opportunities through Orchards and other
local agencies. In addition, they were informed that they
can always obtain additional training at
www.fosterparents.com, and that they will need to maintain
current CPR/First Aid training.
Types of children the family is willing to consider. The family
desires to care for 1 child, male, ages 8-14, with the
following characteristics: general care, child with mental
health diagnosis, sexually abused child, developmentally
disabled child, medical needs child, cross racial, special
education child, ADHD child, medication administration,
unrelated caregiver, and LGBTQIA+2S. Ability and
willingness to care for special needs children, and the
6

problems of the children. The family is able and willing to
meet the needs of children. They are willing and able to
take several characteristics and have received training via
GROW training and CPR/First Aid regarding the
characteristics they chose. They also have experience with
these characteristics due to having a friend who work in
social work/mental health, previous history and being aware
of resources due to history with FP1 daughter and being
observant and aware of the needs of children in general.
• Email from Youth A’s assigned foster care worker to IW on
April 13, 2023. The email stated: “We have really struggled
to find a placement for him as he has been in multiple
residential facilities and two admissions to Hawthorn
Center. He truly has made SIGNIFICANT progress during
this admission at Hawthorn Center. He was admitted in
September 2020 and cleared for discharge on November
16, 2022. Unfortunately, the residential facilities have
probably labeled him in a negative light and are not willing
to give him a chance. It will take a very specific trauma-
informed foster home to take him on. The psychologist at
Hawthorn Center has informed us that she would be willing
to work with a prospective placement to learn his triggers
and to learn strategies to be successful with him as he has
experienced so much trauma and loss in his 12 years of
life”. Attachments to the email include a 1.5-page treatment
update and recommendation summary from Hawthorn
Center that lists current diagnoses and medication. Other
recommendations state, in part, caregivers should receive
psychoeducation on the impact of trauma and prenatal
substance exposure on children. Additional attachments
include RPU slide with a picture of Youth A, about me, my
interests and take a chance on me because sections. Third
attachment is 11-page Individualized Plan of Service and
Nursing Teaching Care Plans for Youth A that included a
brief summary of why Youth A entered care and
precipitating factors that led to him being hospitalized at
Hawthorn. Final attachment is a 9-page placement search
information document that provides an overview of
behaviors, interventions and child welfare history for Youth
A.
• Email from Intensive Placement Unit sent to agency on
April 25, 2023, regarding Youth A. Email includes a link for
Youth A’s MARE video and a short summary of Youth A
that includes an “about me” section, “my interests” section,
“take a chance on me because” section and contact
information for the assigned foster care worker. The body
7

of the email also includes the statement: “Youth A is a 12-
year-old male who has been in care since September 2019,
and he became an MCI ward as of July 28, 2020. Youth is
ready to be discharged from a psychiatric hospital setting
where he has made significant progress and is looking for a
permanent home”. An additional update was provided that
stated: “He was recently accepted into Pine Rest (Lotus
program). This is funded in 90-day increments and is a
transitional placement to a more community like setting”.
• Youth A’s MISCAWIS case file:
o September 9, 2022, MAXIMUS report. Report states
“Youth A received approximately 250 incident
reports, primarily for physically aggressive behavior,
while placed at Wolverine Human Services. Youth A
exhibited self-injurious behaviors, physically
aggressive behaviors (hitting, kicking, shoving), as
well as acute homicidal ideation with plans to kill his
cousin, "kidnap little girls" and kill them, as well as
attempting to kill animals, reportedly stating that he
wants to "see blood splatter". Youth A has treatment
needs that include disruptive mood dysregulation
disorder (DMDD), posttraumatic stress disorder
(PTSD), anxiety, attention-deficit hyperactivity
disorder (ADHD), as well as evidence of a thought
disorder such as hearing voices and believing that
demons are inside of him.”
o Occupational Therapy Assessment dated August 3,
2023. Document lists previous diagnoses as
Disruptive Mood Dysregulation, PTSD, ADHD and
Reactive Attachment Disorder. Behavioral history
includes physical aggression, homicidal ideation and
threats and behavior disturbances.
o DHS 3307 dated October 2, 2023, with FCW and FP
signature. Diagnoses listed are Disruptive Mood
Dysregulation, ADHD-Combined Presentation,
PTSD. History of physical aggression towards peers
and staff at the facilities. Physical restraints and
seclusion have been utilized in the past. History of
abuse or neglect includes exposure to substances
during pregnancy and physical abuse.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as the information
contained in the initial home study (3130) did not adequately
document rationale for recommending several high needs service
types based on completed training and personal experience.
Based on the information contained in the 3130, Youth A was
8

placed in the home despite FP1 and FP2 not being adequately
prepared to meet Youth A’s needs.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
